elements.label: MAIN ARGUMENT: AI video generation apps will cause more harm than benefit to society
CON: The technology already exists and cannot be uninvented
PRO: Current legal frameworks are insufficient
PRO: These apps enable bullying and harassment at unprecedented scale
PRO: Reputational destruction becomes weaponized and democratized
PRO: Epistemic crisis: Society loses ability to determine truth from fiction
PRO: Non-consensual use of likeness violates personal autonomy and dignity
PRO: Amplifies existing power imbalances and inequalities
CON: Democratizes creative video production and storytelling
CON: Creates new forms of entertainment and humor
CON: Reduces barriers to entry for content creation and marketing
CON: Technology itself is neutral; regulation and norms can mitigate harms
CON: Builds media literacy and critical thinking as society adapts
IMPLIES: Debate should focus on harm reduction rather than prevention
PRO: Right of publicity laws vary by jurisdiction and weren"t designed for AI
PRO: Section 230 protections may shield platforms from liability
PRO: International enforcement is nearly impossible
CON: Regulation always lags behind technology and is difficult to enforce globally
PRO: When anyone can create unlimited realistic fake videos, baseline trust in visual evidence erodes
PRO: Legal systems rely on video evidence; this undermines justice mechanisms
CON: Cheaper ads also mean more manipulative/deceptive advertising
PRO: Knowing fake videos exist will make people more skeptical and careful evaluators
PRO: Victims have no effective way to remove millions of generated videos once circulated
PRO: Platform policies and legal frameworks can evolve to address misuse
PRO: Videos appear nearly identical to reality, making false content indistinguishable from real
PRO: Algorithmic reach advantages mean powerful voices drown out corrections
ASSUMPTION: Some level of entertainment/creative value justifies risks
CON: Elderly and less tech-savvy populations particularly vulnerable
ASSUMPTION: Humans can develop and widely deploy critical evaluation skills fast enough
PRO: Enables people without technical skills to express creative visions
PRO: Consent systems can be built requiring opt-in before likeness is used
ASSUMPTION: Speed and ease of creation directly correlates with increased misuse
CON: Platforms can implement verification systems and provenance tracking
PRO: People with more reach will have disproportionate power to spread harmful fake content
PRO: Individual creators can compete with well-funded productions
CON: Society has adapted to previous media disruptions (Photoshop, edited video)
ASSUMPTION: Individuals have inherent right to control use of their own image
CON: Misinformation research shows people are poor at detecting fakes even when warned
CON: Existing platforms already have deepfake problems; these apps just make it more visible
CON: Democratization also democratizes harm, making the net effect negative
PRO: Enables new art forms and creative expression not previously possible
PRO: Existing right of publicity laws are inadequate for mass AI generation
PRO: Small businesses can create ad campaigns without hiring production companies
PRO: Millions of videos can be created using someone"s face without their knowledge or permission
ASSUMPTION: Visual media is currently trusted as more reliable than text
CON: Entertainment value doesn"t outweigh potential for harm
PRO: Videos described as "funny" - provides joy and social bonding
PRO: Marginalized groups already face disproportionate online harassment
PRO: Removes need for expensive equipment, actors, locations, editing expertise
PRO: Once viral, fake videos can destroy careers, relationships, and opportunities before debunking occurs
PRO: Deepfakes can be created in seconds with simple prompts, making harassment campaigns trivially easy
PRO: Women, LGBTQ+ individuals, and minorities likely to be targeted with fake explicit/harmful content
PRO: AI Video generation apps aren"t really solving any significant problems for humanity
PRO: Media literacy education can help people develop skepticism
PRO: Lowered costs enable spam-level ad production and market saturation
PRO: History shows that technology accessibility increases both positive and negative uses
PRO: Enforcement is nearly impossible once videos are distributed across platforms/jurisdictions
PRO: Viral fake content spreads faster than corrections/debunking
PRO: Influencers and verified accounts get algorithmic amplification
PRO: Content moderation at scale has consistently failed for other harmful content types
CON: But video feels more "real" than photos - psychological impact is greater
PRO: Environmental costs are substantial and unjustified
PRO: AI content raises dopamine baseline, making human content boring by comparison
CON: Speculative unknown benefits don"t justify concrete known harms
PRO: Creates mental health crisis through overstimulation
PRO: Hyper-stimulation degrades human experience and mental health
CON: Multiple apps, cross-posting, and TV exposure means individual limits are meaningless
ASSUMPTION: Job quality and fulfillment matters, not just job quantity
CON: New legal infrastructure creates jobs that offset creative losses
CON: New legal jobs required to fight lawsuits are not better than displaced creative jobs
PRO: Societal values embodied in where money flows
PRO: Economic transformation represents net negative for human flourishing
PRO: Shifts society from physical-augmented-by-digital to fully-digital existence
PRO: Creative labor displacement without equivalent replacement
PRO: Empowerment narrative is hollow because training data reflects dominant narratives
CON: Apps implement screen time limits to protect users
PRO: Training data bias means apparent democratization reinforces existing power structures
PRO: Innovation stifling: Regulation might prevent beneficial uses we haven"t imagined
PRO: Less lawsuits is probably a good indicator for better societal health
PRO: Individual harm reduction measures are meaningless in ecosystem of content abundance
PRO: Marginalized voices get tools to tell the same old stories in their own face - not true liberation
COMPLICATES: If you don"t tell your own story, someone else will
PRO: Like arguing your new more lethal form of alcohol is healthy because the bar closes early - when there are 5 more bars right across the street
PRO: Society puts money where it wants to create more of things
QUESTION: What kind of work makes human life meaningful?
QUESTION: Is a society of ad-sellers better than a society of artists?
PRO: We"re trading real harm now for maybe-benefits later
PRO: Why watch real Olympics when AI can show impossible feats?
COMPLICATES: You can tell your story, but so can everyone else - empowerment is doubled-edged
IMPLIES: Don"t download AI-video generation apps or use social platforms that host this content prominently
PRO: Carbon emissions per video generation accumulate at massive scale
PRO: Creative work provides higher job satisfaction than advertising work
PRO: Inability to enjoy normal life experiences after exposure to hyper-stimulation
PRO: Ratio of new legal jobs to lost creative jobs is extremely unfavorable (1:100 or worse)
PRO: Depression and anhedonia result from dopamine baseline shift
CON: Traditional film production also has high environmental costs
PRO: Structural inequality persists despite surface-level access to tools
PRO: Money flows to ad-selling platforms, not creative workers
PRO: Lawyer job satisfaction vs artist job satisfaction shows qualitative difference
PRO: Human creators must compete with infinite impossible spectacle
PRO: Historical precedent shows automation typically creates fewer, different jobs than it displaces
PRO: Loss of shared reality and shared human experience
PRO: Loss of narrative control is itself a harm to personal autonomy
CON: Traditional production creates fewer, more valuable pieces per unit of environmental cost
PRO: Millions/billions of videos create cumulative environmental impact
PRO: Water usage for data center cooling to generate videos is significant
PRO: Human performances (Olympics, sports, dance) lose appeal compared to AI spectacle
PRO: AI videos provoke laughter and engagement that doesn"t usually happen with regular content
PRO: Videographers, editors, animators, actors lose income streams
PRO: Precautionary principle: when facing uncertainty with potential for serious harm, err toward caution
PRO: Hours of hyper-dopaminergic content consumption
PRO: Systemic/regulatory approach needed, not user-level controls
PRO: Reality becomes boring compared to simulation
PRO: AI models cannot generate truly novel narratives outside their training distribution
PRO: Novelty plus impossibility creates higher engagement than reality-based content
PRO: More ad-sales jobs, fewer creative jobs changes societal composition
PRO: Training data predominantly reflects Western, white, male-dominated content and perspectives
PRO: Mental health outcomes differ by profession type - creative vs commercial
Resource To Learn About AI Video

elements.description: This article discusses the various ways in which facts can be manipulated or misrepresented to mislead audiences. It explores techniques used in media and communication to distort truth and influence public perception.
elements.label: How To Mislead With Facts

elements.description: This article discusses the complexities and consequences of bad faith communication, exploring its implications in various contexts.
elements.label: The Endgames of Bad Faith Communication
